STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 31, 2025
KENDRA LEE SPANJER
OTTAWA COUNTY DHHS
12185 JAMES ST,
HOLLAND, MI, 49424-9622
RE: License#: CP700201350
Dear KENDRA LEE SPANJER:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 7/28/25-7/30/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of Seven open files of youth in care (6 foster care & 1 IL) contained one
updated service plan that was not completed timely.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was offered regarding the need to obtain documentation of
well-child examinations from the medical provider.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was provided regarding the documentation of a foster parents'
preference regarding SOGIE of youths placed in the home as the language used
in some of the reports reviewed could be more specific.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The one
CAP submitted by the agency during the period under review was in response to
the 9/24/2024 licensing inspection report and was approved on 10/10/2024. That
CAP addressed five violations, two of which were MDHHS policy requirements no
longer regulated by DCWL. The remaining three violations were related to special
evaluations completion, initial service plan timeliness, and worker visits with foster
youth in their placement. Each of those violations were established within one file,
respectively and the corrective action plan was implemented successfully as
evidenced by those violations not being repeated during this inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator was reviewed and discussed during the exit meeting. The
chief administrator reported one foster care supervisor left the department in
February and there were not enough staff to warrant hiring in her place, so the
existing staff were dispersed amongst agency supervisors. The chief administrator
indicated there have been staffing changes; however, they have been able to
maintain caseload compliance. There have been some compliance issues due to
caseload changes and staff performance issues, but nothing pervasive.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
The two foster care supervisors and licensing supervisor were present during the
entrance meeting. They reported the year has been somewhat difficult with staff
performance issues and staffing changes, as well as policy/licensing rule changes,
but they have been providing support and assistance to their staff to ensure tasks
are completed timely and accurately. The two workers interviewed (one licensing
and one foster care) reported there have been challenges resulting from staff
changes, but supervisors are supportive and helpful. They both stated their
respective supervisors are always available and easy to reach and will assist them
whenever needed. No concerns were reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency office has adequate space and equipment for the delivery of foster
care, independent living, and certification services. Physical CHRI is stored

securely within locked drawers in the licensing supervisor's office. A cross
shredder is also present in the office and multiple cross shredders are in the office.
Closed adoption files are locked in cabinets which are located in the main office.
All other files are stored securely within the office.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
July 30, 2025
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 31, 2025

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
